brief_description of the content in the: The JetBrains Inspectopedia page describes a rule that checks for invalid prefixes in the @ConfigurationProperties annotations in Spring Boot. The rule triggers for classes annotated with @ConfigurationProperties that are not registered via @EnableConfigurationProperties, marked as a Spring component, or scanned via @ConfigurationPropertiesScan. The invalid prefixes include missing, empty, duplicate prefixes, and prefixes in a notation other than kebab-case.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'invalid-configuration-properties' checks all classes in the application. If a class is annotated with @ConfigurationProperties and is not registered via @EnableConfigurationProperties or does not have any other annotations, it retrieves the 'prefix' attribute from the @ConfigurationProperties annotation. It then asserts that the prefix is not empty, is unique, and starts with a hyphen (indicating kebab-case). If the assertion fails, it generates a message indicating the invalid prefix and the fully qualified name of the class.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
https://www.baeldung.com/configuration-properties-in-spring-boot: This Baeldung article provides a comprehensive guide on using @ConfigurationProperties in Spring Boot, including how to define and validate properties. It does not specifically address the rule generated but provides context for understanding its importance.

https://reflectoring.io/validate-spring-boot-configuration-parameters-at-startup/: This Reflectoring article discusses how to validate configuration parameters at startup in Spring Boot, which is relevant to the rule generated as it involves checking the validity of @ConfigurationProperties.
